BTC Patient Discussion Forums > Public Forums > Dupuytren's Disease > Collagenase injection in trial  Forum Quick Jump
 
  
[ << Previous Thread | Next Thread >> | Show Newest Post First ]

Kent L
Registered Member


Date Joined Nov 2007
Total Posts : 5
  		   Posted 11/10/2007 3:39 PM (GMT -4)   
I just received my first collagenase injection in Auxilium's trial on 11/8/07. Here's a quick progress report:

I received the live injection at 3 pm. (not the placebo) about 5 hours after the injection I could feel the heat and aching as the collagenase began to dissolve tissue. My injection was on the pip joint of my right little finger. Light to moderate discomfort continued for about 3 hours until 11pm. Pain subsided and I had no problems overnight. Next morning the pip joint showed some bruising at the injection site and the back of my hand was quite swollen. At 1 pm on 11/9, the doctor "popped" the adhesion, which wasn't the most pleasant thing, but the pain was short lived. I received a splint to wear at night for the next 4 months. It's very comfortable and should be easy to tolerate.

My little finger is now completely straight and only had a little continued sensitivity at the injection site. Hand is still quite swollen but feels pretty good. The whole process is quite fascinating and is much better tolerated than surgery. I've heard that the instance of regrowth has been quite low in phase II study subjects, so I'm very optimistic.

I'll post updates as the week progresses. So far, it's been worth the wait!
Back to Top
 

Elbert Wicks
''


Date Joined Jun 2007
Total Posts : 2
  		   Posted 11/10/2007 4:57 PM (GMT -4)   
How would you compare the procedure with the N/A procedure from your experience of knowing about the N/A for D/C procedure?
Back to Top
 

J Ann
Registered Member


Date Joined Jul 2007
Total Posts : 10
  		   Posted 11/10/2007 5:49 PM (GMT -4)   

Kent,

  Thanks for your story on your injection, I should get my first on on the 19th and have been a little apprehensive on participating in this Auxilium AA4500 study. My contracture is also in my pip of my dominate hand ( really need to be able to use it and not miss work) with a 45 degree contracture and would love to see it straight again! But this study in Indianapolis is a blind study so I may not even get the drug but will still have to go tru all the procedures for the first 3 months and then would be able to get the drug at that time. It sounds like I will now after the first injection. ( with the heat sensation you mentioned) keep my posted as I will to you.

J Ann

Back to Top
 

Kent L
Registered Member


Date Joined Nov 2007
Total Posts : 5
  		   Posted 11/11/2007 1:53 PM (GMT -4)   
I can't really comment on NA (needle aponeurotomy) since I've not experienced it personally, however, I've heard that the injection method should provide the least amount of trauma and therefore the least chance of regrowth of the other alternatives. (NA or surgery)

All my lesions can be tracked back precisely to injuries, so I was very concerned about surgery, since that would just stimulate the scarring that caused my lesions in the first place.

It's now the fourth day after injection and I can still feel small bits of adhesions coming loose, like little pinpricks. I've done a bit of limited stretching of the joint. Swelling has gone down a bit, but is still prevalent. We are supposed to do a series of hand exercises 4 times a day. I started them this morning and can tell a big difference in the swelling. I probably should have started exercising immediately as recommended.

One big difference in the injection vs. NA is that the collagenase will literally dissolve some of the lesion itself, where NA leaves all the scar tissue intact, just disconnected. My pip lesion was unusual, on the SIDE of my little finger rather than the palm, and there was a large nodule that stuck out and was constantly getting hooked on stuff. The doctor injected that nodule and now it's nothing more than a black and blue sack of fluid. (gross, I know) But I'll be very happy for that nodule to be gone!

Post Edited (Kent L) : 11/11/2007 12:00:41 PM (GMT-5)

Back to Top
 

Kent L
Registered Member


Date Joined Nov 2007
Total Posts : 5
  		   Posted 11/11/2007 1:59 PM (GMT -4)   
J Ann,

Your hand will be pretty sore on days two (the "popping" day) and three, but functional. I got a lot of relief by icing my hand several times a day. I was told that one of my study members tried to play golf after his injection. Not recommended!

By day four, things have improved significantly and I can do most stuff with my hand. In fact, the biggest problem on day four is the swelling, which prevents me from making a fist so you'll feel a bit ham handed. (literally) I expect almost full recovery by day five.
Back to Top
 

J Ann
Registered Member


Date Joined Jul 2007
Total Posts : 10
  		   Posted 11/11/2007 8:19 PM (GMT -4)   
Thanks for the info Kent I will let you know how my first injection goes!
Back to Top
 

Tim
Registered Member


Date Joined Nov 2007
Total Posts : 1
  		   Posted 11/13/2007 10:27 PM (GMT -4)   
It's day 7, second month of trail for me. Two months of injections in right small finger. The contacture was pretty severe, about 70 degress and now it's at about 10 degrees. The doctors (and me) are very happy with the results. Pain of injections was tolerable, pain of manipulation must have been tolerable because I'm still here - but it was very - very painful. I had surgery 03/2005 which, due to scar tissue, makes the cords a little trickier than some.
Back to Top
 

speedracer
Registered Member


Date Joined Nov 2007
Total Posts : 3
  		   Posted 11/13/2007 10:53 PM (GMT -4)   
I wonder if anybody has tried Santyl collagenase applied to the skin above the Dupuytren lumps?. If the injections of AA4500 are working why wouldn't the collagenase ointment pass through a few layers of skin to do same thing? My Dupuytrens has gone in remission and lesions seem to have shrunk since I went vegan a couple of years ago at which time I quit taking Viagra since I don't need it anymore.
Back to Top
 

Kent L
Registered Member


Date Joined Nov 2007
Total Posts : 5
  		   Posted 12/13/2007 12:03 PM (GMT -4)   
I go in for my one month followup today. My lesion was a bit different than most, on the SIDE of the pip joint. (running down the side of the little finger of my right hand) I can still feel some lesion tissue that runs down the length of the tendon. Otherwise my right hand would be indistinguishable from the left. The lesions seem to shrink a bit for a couple of weeks after injection. Now I've got to decide whether to have a second round of injections, just to clean things up a bit and eliminate the beginnings of a second lesion on my middle finger.

But so far the results are great! My little finger is about 95% back to normal.
Back to Top
 

moondanc
Registered Member


Date Joined Dec 2007
Total Posts : 1
  		   Posted 12/14/2007 12:55 AM (GMT -4)   

Collagenase vs NA
 I had NA 2.5 years ago for my right hand ring finger MCP joint.  It was a piece of cake.  However, about 6 months ago the Dupuytren’s returned with a vengeance and progressed to a 35-4-% contracture ( it also appeared in the palm of my left hand and the PIP joint of 2 fingers).  I'm in a Phase III trial and had my first collagenase injection on Monday.  It's one of the studies where 2/3 receive study med-collagenase-- and 1/3 receive a placebo.  Luckily, I received the study med.  However, I found the injections directly into the cord quite painful--although short-- and the stiffness, bruising and swelling -- 3 days later still existing-  quite unpleasant.  I had partial "popping" spontaneously overnight but the rest of the procedure to finish the "popping" on Tuesday was extremely unpleasant.  My finger straightened to nearly 0%/normal almost immediately but I must stretch it (my study doc recommended sitting on it!) at least 4 times a day to keep it that way.  I was also told not to use any ice OR heat on my hand for at least 72 hours so as not to inactivate the collagenase that apparently is still working.  Even though my finger is straight, the adhesions/connections in my palm have not been released the way they were with NA although the lumps have softened somewhat.  The study doc maintains that NA has a 50-70% recurrence rate and that even that number is suspect because no real studies have been done.  He also says the recurrence rate with the collagenase is much lower.

 

As of this moment unless there's a really, really low recurrence rate with collagenase, I'd opt for NA!  When I had the NA procedure, I went back to the hotel, napped for an hour and was out shopping with no pain, bruising or other side effects.

 
Back to Top
